subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns
msgSnippet: ... Hm, some of these items seem to be bad ideas. But anti pattern sounds too strong for my taste. Anyhow... No unit tests: sounds like saying you sing wrong

On Friday 17 February 2006 18:24, Joe Schmetzer wrote:
> I've just updated the JUnit Anti-patterns page I maintain at
> http://www.exubero.com/junit/antipatterns.html. I'd be interested in
> any feedback, if people want to suggest additions or improvements.

Hm, some of these items seem to be bad ideas. But anti pattern sounds too 
strong for my taste. 
Anyhow...

No unit tests: sounds like saying "you sing wrong because you don't sing 
at all". If I don't test, I surley do something wrong, but I am not doing 
unit testing wrong.

I don't like the section heading "Refactoring" because a refactoring is 
something different. Your 'refactorings' actively change the code and its 
behavior, while AFAIK a refactoring in terms of THE book doesn't do that. 
Maybe 'fixes' or 'solutions' would be better headings?

Missing assertions may be ok, for example in a test that was written for a 
bug report where the code threw but shouldn't do so. This test can just 
have a comment like // This line throws if bug 123 is not fixed.

I also don't have problems with multiple assertions, if it's only two or 
three. For example I may assert some object to be not null before 
asserting its properties.

Superficial coverage: this can happen for TDD beginners, and unless there 
is a requirement to check something not on the happy path, I wouldn't 
make this a hard rule. For example, if I write tests that deal with 
people's age (as an integer), I see no problem with not testing negative 
values, if the code is used in a context where this is other classes 
responsibility.

An example for the "only easy tests" section would be helpful.

I agree on the overly complex tests. However, you may not always be able 
to just refactor as you'd like.

You could add time/date and randomness to the external dependencies.

Cheers,

Robert
